thread.title: Shake Shack’s stock sinks after analyst says sell
thread.title_full: Shake Shack’s stock sinks after analyst says sell - MarketWatch

author: By     Tomi Kilgore
title: Shake Shack’s stock sinks after analyst says sell
text:
FactSet ‘Expensive any way you shake it’ Shake Shack Inc.’s stock sank over 9% in midday trade Tuesday, after Morgan Stanley recommended investors sell the stock, citing an “extreme disconnect” between value and price.
Analyst John Glass cut his rating to underweight/sell, after being at equal weight/hold since he started covering the burger chain in February. His $38 stock price target is 29% below current levels.
“...the difference between what we see as fair value and current market price represents an extreme disconnect.” Morgan Stanley analyst John Glass The selloff put the stock SHAK, -7.22% on track to close at the lowest level since April 9, and 42% below its May 22 record close of $92.86. Shake Shack went public on Jan. 30 at an initial public offering price of $21.
Don’t miss: Shake Shack introduces its first chicken sandwich .
Glass said he believes the company’s fundamental story remains “strong and intact,” but that is more than compensated for in current valuations. Basically, Glass said the stock is “expensive any way you shake it.”
The stock’s price-to-earnings ratio of about 407, according to FactSet, is more than six times what Glass said was the high-growth peer average of 65.
Glass also expressed some concern that the supply of shares will increase soon, as the standard six-month post-IPO lockup expires later this month.
“While post IPO euphoria and elevated valuations are not new or unique to [Shake Shack], the difference between what we see as fair value and current market price represents an extreme disconnect,” he wrote in a note to clients.
